TEXT: A noise of bolts was now heard,  the door opened,  and two men appeared.

One was short, very muscular, broad-shouldered, with robust limbs, strong head, an abundance of black hair, thick moustache, a quick penetrating look, and the vivacity which characterises the population of [Southern France]_n0.
The second stranger merits a more detailed description.

[I]_p0 made out [his]_p1 prevailing qualities directly: self-confidence,  because [his]_p2 head was well set on [his]_p2 shoulders,  and [his]_p3 black eyes looked around with cold assurance calmness,  for [his]_p3 skin,  rather pale,  showed [his]_p3 coolness of blood energy,  evinced by the rapid contraction of [his]_p4 lofty brows and courage,  because [his]_p4 deep breathing denoted great power of lungs.
Whether this person was thirty-five or fifty years of age,  [I]_p9 could not say.
[He]_p10 was tall,  had a large forehead,  straight nose,  a clearly cut mouth,  beautiful teeth,  with fine taper hands,  indicative of a highly nervous temperament.
This man was certainly the most admirable specimen [I]_p11 had ever met.
One particular feature was [his]_p12 eyes,  rather far from each other,  and which could take in nearly a quarter of the horizon at once.
This faculty, (I verified [it]_p13 later), gave [him]_p14 a range of vision far superior to [Ned Land]_n1 's.

When this stranger fixed upon an object,  [his]_p15 eyebrows met,  [his]_p16 large eyelids closed around so as to contract the range of [his]_p16 vision,  and [he]_p18 looked as if [he]_p19 magnified the objects lessened by distance,  as if [he]_p19 pierced those sheets of water so opaque to [our]_p22 eyes,  and as if [he]_p20 read the very depths of the seas.
The two strangers,  with caps made from the fur of the sea otter,  and shod with sea boots of seal's skin,  were dressed in clothes of a particular texture,  which allowed free movement of the limbs.

The taller of the two,  evidently the chief on board,  examined [us]_p23 with great attention,  without saying a word then,  turning to [his]_p24 companion,  talked with [him]_p25 in an unknown tongue.
[It]_p26 was a sonorous,  harmonious,  and flexible dialect,  the vowels seeming to admit of very varied accentuation.
The other replied by a shake of the head,  and added two or three perfectly incomprehensible words.
Then [he]_p27 seemed to question [me]_p28 by a look.
[I]_p29 replied in good [French]_n2 that [I]_p30 did not know [his]_p31 language but [he]_p32 seemed not to understand [me]_p33, and [my]_p34 situation became more embarrassing.
"If master were to tell [our]_p35 story ,"said [Conseil]_n3 ,"perhaps these gentlemen may understand some words.
" [I]_p36 began to tell [our]_p37 adventures,  articulating each syllable clearly,  and without omitting one single detail.
[I]_p38 announced [our]_p39 names and rank, introducing in person [Professor Aronnax]_n4, [his]_p40 servant [Conseil]_n5, and master [Ned Land]_n6, the harpooner.
The man with the soft calm eyes listened to [me]_p41 quietly,  even politely,  and with extreme attention but nothing in [his]_p42 countenance indicated that [he]_p43 had understood [my]_p44 story.
When [I]_p45 finished,  [he]_p46 said not a word.
There remained one resource, to speak [English]_n7.
Perhaps [they]_p47 would know this almost universal language.
[I]_p48 knew [it]_p49,  as well as the German language,  well enough to read [it]_p50 fluently,  but not to speak [it]_p50 correctly.
But,  anyhow,  [we]_p52 must make [ourselves]_p53 understood.
"Go on in [your]_p54 turn ,"[I]_p56 said to the harpooner"speak [your]_p55 best [Anglo-Saxon]_n8, and try to do better than [I]_p57.
"[Ned]_n9 did not beg off, and recommenced [our]_p58 story.
To [his]_p59 great disgust,  the harpooner did not seem to have made [himself]_p60 more intelligible than [I]_p61 had.
[Our]_p62 visitors did not stir.
[They]_p63 evidently understood neither the language of [England]_n10 nor of [France]_n11.

Very much embarrassed, after having vainly exhausted [our]_p64 speaking resources, [I]_p65 knew not what part to take, when [Conseil]_n12 said:"If master will permit [me]_p67, [I]_p66 will relate [it]_p68 in German.
" But in spite of the elegant terms and good accent of the narrator,  the German language had no success.
At last, nonplussed, [I]_p69 tried to remember [my]_p70 first lessons, and to narrate [our]_p71 adventures in [Latin]_n13, but with no better success.
This last attempt being of no avail,  the two strangers exchanged some words in [their]_p72 unknown language,  and retired.
The door shut.
"[It]_p73 is an infamous shame ,"cried [Ned Land]_n14, who broke out for the twentieth time.

"[We]_p74 speak to those rogues in [French]_n15, [English]_n16, German, and [Latin]_n17, and not one of [them]_p75 has the politeness to answer!""Calm [yourself]_p76 ,"[I]_p77 said to the impetuous [Ned]_n18"anger will do no good.

""But do [you]_p78 see, [Professor]_n19 ,"replied [our]_p79 irascible companion ,"that [we]_p80 shall absolutely die of hunger in this iron cage?""[Bah]_n20 !"said [Conseil]_n21, philosophically"[we]_p81 can hold out some time yet.
" "[My]_p82 friends, " [I]_p83 said,  "[we]_p84 must not despair.
[We]_p85 have been worse off than this.
Do [me]_p86 the favour to wait a little before forming an opinion upon the commander and crew of this boat.
""[My]_p87 opinion is formed ,"replied [Ned Land]_n22, sharply.
"[They]_p88 are rascals.

""Good! and from what country?""From the land of rogues!""[My]_p89 brave [Ned]_n23, that country is not clearly indicated on the map of the world but [I]_p90 admit that the nationality of the two strangers is hard to determine.
Neither [English]_n24, [French]_n25, nor German, that is quite certain.
However,  [I]_p91 am inclined to think that the commander and [his]_p92 companion were born in low latitudes.
There is southern blood in [them]_p93.
But [I]_p94 cannot decide by [their]_p95 appearance whether [they]_p96 are Spaniards,  Turks,  Arabians,  or Indians.
As to [their]_p97 language,  [it]_p98 is quite incomprehensible.
""There is the disadvantage of not knowing all languages ,"said [Conseil]_n26 ,"or the disadvantage of not having one universal language.
" As [he]_p99 said these words,  the door opened.
A steward entered.
[He]_p100 brought [us]_p101 clothes,  coats and trousers,  made of a stuff [I]_p102 did not know.
[I]_p103 hastened to dress [myself]_p104,  and [my]_p105 companions followed [my]_p106 example.
During that time,  the steward,  dumb,  perhaps deaf,  had arranged the table,  and laid three plates.
"This is something like!"said [Conseil]_n27.
"[Bah]_n28 !"said the angry harpooner ,"what do [you]_p107 suppose [they]_p108 eat here? [Tortoise]_n29 liver, filleted shark, and beef steaks from seadogs.
""[We]_p109 shall see ,"said [Conseil]_n30.
The dishes,  of bell metal,  were placed on the table,  and [we]_p110 took [our]_p111 places.

Undoubtedly [we]_p112 had to do with civilised people, and, had [it]_p113 not been for the electric light which flooded [us]_p114, [I]_p115 could have fancied [I]_p116 was in the dining-room of the [Adelphi Hotel]_n31 at [Liverpool]_n32, or at the [Grand Hotel]_n33 in [Paris]_n34.
[I]_p117 must say,  however,  that there was neither bread nor wine.
The water was fresh and clear, but [it]_p118 was water and did not suit [Ned Land]_n35 's taste.

Amongst the dishes which were brought to [us]_p119,  [I]_p120 recognised several fish delicately dressed but of some,  although excellent,  [I]_p121 could give no opinion,  neither could [I]_p121 tell to what kingdom [they]_p123 belonged,  whether animal or vegetable.
As to the dinner-service,  [it]_p124 was elegant,  and in perfect taste.

Each utensil,  spoon,  fork,  knife,  plate,  had a letter engraved on [it]_p125,  with a motto above [it]_p126,  of which this is an exact facsimile: MOBILIS IN MOBILI N The letter N was no doubt the initial of the name of the enigmatical person who commanded at the bottom of the seas.
[Ned]_n36 and [Conseil]_n37 did not reflect much.
[They]_p127 devoured the food,  and [I]_p128 did likewise.
[I]_p129 was,  besides,  reassured as to [our]_p130 fate and [it]_p132 seemed evident that [our]_p131 hosts would not let [us]_p133 die of want.
However,  everything has an end,  everything passes away,  even the hunger of people who have not eaten for fifteen hours.
[Our]_p134 appetites satisfied,  [we]_p135 felt overcome with sleep.
"Faith! [I]_p136 shall sleep well ,"said [Conseil]_n38.
"So shall [I]_p137 ,"replied [Ned Land]_n39.
[My]_p138 two companions stretched [themselves]_p139 on the cabin carpet,  and were soon sound asleep.
For [my]_p140 own part,  too many thoughts crowded [my]_p141 brain,  too many insoluble questions pressed upon [me]_p143,  too many fancies kept [my]_p141 eyes half open.
Where were we? What strange power carried [us]_p144 on? [I]_p145 felt,  or rather fancied [I]_p146 felt,  the machine sinking down to the lowest beds of the sea.

Dreadful nightmares beset [me]_p147 [I]_p148 saw in these mysterious asylums a world of unknown animals,  amongst which this submarine boat seemed to be of the same kind,  living,  moving,  and formidable as [they]_p149.
Then [my]_p150 brain grew calmer,  [my]_p151 imagination wandered into vague unconsciousness,  and [I]_p152 soon fell into a deep sleep.
CHAPTER IX [NED LAND]_n40 'S TEMPERS How long [we]_p153 slept [I]_p154 do not know but [our]_p155 sleep must have lasted long, for [it]_p157 rested [us]_p158 completely from [our]_p156 fatigues.
[I]_p159 woke first.
[My]_p160 companions had not moved,  and were still stretched in [their]_p161 corner.
Hardly roused from [my]_p162 somewhat hard couch,  [I]_p165 felt [my]_p163 brain freed,  [my]_p163 mind clear.
[I]_p166 then began an attentive examination of [our]_p167 cell.
Nothing was changed inside.
The prison was still a prison,  the prisoners,  prisoners.
However,  the steward,  during [our]_p168 sleep,  had cleared the table.
[I]_p169 breathed with difficulty.
The heavy air seemed to oppress [my]_p170 lungs.
Although the cell was large,  [we]_p171 had evidently consumed a great part of the oxygen that [it]_p172 contained.
Indeed,  each man consumes,  in one hour,  the oxygen contained in more than 176 pints of air,  and this air,  charged (as then) with a nearly equal quantity of carbonic acid,  becomes unbreathable.
[It]_p173 became necessary to renew the atmosphere of [our]_p174 prison,  and no doubt the whole in the submarine boat.
That gave rise to a question in [my]_p175 mind.

How would the commander of this floating dwelling-place proceed? Would [he]_p176 obtain air by chemical means, in getting by heat the oxygen contained in chlorate of potash, and in absorbing carbonic acid by caustic potash? [Or]_n41, a more convenient, economical, and consequently more probable alternative, would [he]_p177 be satisfied to rise and take breath at the surface of the water, like a whale, and so renew for twenty-four hours the atmospheric provision? In fact, [I]_p178 was already obliged to increase [my]_p180 respirations to eke out of this cell the little oxygen [it]_p181 contained, when suddenly [I]_p179 was refreshed by a current of pure air, and perfumed with saline emanations.
[It]_p182 was an invigorating sea breeze,  charged with iodine.
[I]_p183 opened [my]_p184 mouth wide,  and [my]_p185 lungs saturated [themselves]_p186 with fresh particles.
At the same time [I]_p187 felt the boat rolling.
The iron-plated monster had evidently just risen to the surface of the ocean to breathe,  after the fashion of whales.
[I]_p188 found out from that the mode of ventilating the boat.
When [I]_p189 had inhaled this air freely,  [I]_p190 sought the conduit pipe,  which conveyed to [us]_p192 the beneficial whiff,  and [I]_p190 was not long in finding [it]_p193.
Above the door was a ventilator,  through which volumes of fresh air renewed the impoverished atmosphere of the cell.
[I]_p194 was making [my]_p195 observations, when [Ned]_n42 and [Conseil]_n43 awoke almost at the same time, under the influence of this reviving air.
[They]_p196 rubbed [their]_p197 eyes,  stretched [themselves]_p199,  and were on [their]_p198 feet in an instant.
"Did master sleep well?"asked [Conseil]_n44, with [his]_p200 usual politeness.
"Very well,  [my]_p201 brave boy.
And [you]_p202, [Mr Land]_n45 ?""Soundly, [Professor]_n46.
But, [I]_p203 don't know if [I]_p204 am right or not, there seems to be a sea breeze!"A seaman could not be mistaken, and [I]_p204 told the [Canadian]_n47 all that had passed during [his]_p206 sleep.
"Good!" said [he]_p207.
"That accounts for those roarings [we]_p208 heard, when the supposed narwhal sighted the [Abraham Lincoln]_n48.
""Quite so, [Master Land]_n49 [it]_p209 was taking breath.
""Only, [Mr Aronnax]_n50, [I]_p210 have no idea what o'clock [it]_p211 is, unless [it]_p212 is dinner-time.
" "Dinner-time! [my]_p213 good fellow? Say rather breakfast-time,  for [we]_p214 certainly have begun another day.
""So ,"said [Conseil]_n51 ,"[we]_p215 have slept twenty-four hours?""That is [my]_p216 opinion.
""[I]_p217 will not contradict [you]_p218 ,"replied [Ned Land]_n52.
"But,  dinner or breakfast,  the steward will be welcome,  whichever [he]_p219 brings.
""[Master Land]_n53, [we]_p220 must conform to the rules on board, and [I]_p221 suppose [our]_p222 appetites are in advance of the dinner hour.
""That is just like [you]_p223, friend [Conseil]_n54 ,"said [Ned]_n55, impatiently.

"[You]_p224 are never out of temper,  always calm [you]_p225 would return thanks before grace,  and die of hunger rather than complain!" Time was getting on,  and [we]_p226 were fearfully hungry and this time the steward did not appear.
[It]_p227 was rather too long to leave [us]_p228,  if [they]_p230 really had good intentions towards [us]_p229.

[Ned Land]_n56, tormented by the cravings of hunger, got still more angry and, notwithstanding [his]_p231 promise, [I]_p232 dreaded an explosion when [he]_p233 found [himself]_p234 with one of the crew.
For two hours more [Ned Land]_n57 's temper increased [he]_p235 cried, [he]_p236 shouted, but in vain.
The walls were deaf.
There was no sound to be heard in the boat all was still as death.
[It]_p237 did not move,  for [I]_p238 should have felt the trembling motion of the hull under the influence of the screw.
Plunged in the depths of the waters,  [it]_p239 belonged no longer to earth: this silence was dreadful.
[I]_p240 felt terrified, [Conseil]_n58 was calm, [Ned Land]_n59 roared.
Just then a noise was heard outside.
Steps sounded on the metal flags.
The locks were turned,  the door opened,  and the steward appeared.
Before [I]_p241 could rush forward to stop [him]_p242, the [Canadian]_n60 had thrown [him]_p243 down, and held [him]_p243 by the throat.
The steward was choking under the grip of [his]_p245 powerful hand.

[Conseil]_n61 was already trying to unclasp the harpooner's hand from [his]_p246 half-suffocated victim, and [I]_p247 was going to fly to the rescue, when suddenly [I]_p248 was nailed to the spot by hearing these words in [French]_n62 :"Be quiet, [Master Land]_n63 and [you]_p249, [Professor]_n64, will [you]_p250 be so good as to listen to me?"CHAPTER X THE MAN OF THE [SEAS]_n65 [It]_p251 was the commander of the vessel who thus spoke.
At these words, [Ned Land]_n66 rose suddenly.
The steward,  nearly strangled,  tottered out on a sign from [his]_p252 master.
But such was the power of the commander on board, that not a gesture betrayed the resentment which this man must have felt towards the [Canadian]_n67.
[Conseil]_n68 interested in spite of [himself]_p253, [I]_p254 stupefied, awaited in silence the result of this scene.
The commander,  leaning against the corner of a table with [his]_p255 arms folded,  scanned [us]_p256 with profound attention.
Did [he]_p257 hesitate to speak? Did [he]_p258 regret the words which [he]_p258 had just spoken in [French]_n69 ? [One]_p260 might almost think so.

After some moments of silence, which not one of [us]_p261 dreamed of breaking ,"[Gentlemen]_n70 ,"said [he]_p262, in a calm and penetrating voice ,"[I]_p263 speak [French]_n71, [English]_n72, German, and [Latin]_n73 equally well.
[I]_p264 could,  therefore,  have answered [you]_p266 at [our]_p268 first interview,  but [I]_p265 wished to know [you]_p267 first,  then to reflect.
The story told by each one,  entirely agreeing in the main points,  convinced [me]_p269 of [your]_p270 identity.
[I]_p271 know now that chance has brought before [me]_p272 M.

[Pierre Aronnax]_n74, [Professor]_n75 of [Natural]_n76 History at the [Museum]_n77 of [Paris]_n78, entrusted with a scientific mission abroad, [Conseil]_n79, [his]_p273 servant, and [Ned Land]_n80, of [Canadian]_n81 origin, harpooner on board the frigate [Abraham Lincoln]_n82 of the navy of the [United States]_n83 of [America]_n84.
" [I]_p274 bowed assent.
[It]_p275 was not a question that the commander put to [me]_p276.
Therefore there was no answer to be made.
This man expressed [himself]_p277 with perfect ease,  without any accent.
[His]_p278 sentences were well turned,  [his]_p279 words clear,  and [his]_p280 fluency of speech remarkable.
Yet,  [I]_p281 did not recognise in [him]_p282 a fellow-countryman.
[He]_p283 continued the conversation in these terms: "[You]_p284 have doubtless thought,  sir,  that [I]_p285 have delayed long in paying [you]_p286 this second visit.
The reason is that,  [your]_p287 identity recognised,  [I]_p288 wished to weigh maturely what part to act towards [you]_p289.
[I]_p290 have hesitated much.
Most annoying circumstances have brought [you]_p291 into the presence of a man who has broken all the ties of humanity.
[You]_p292 have come to trouble [my]_p293 existence.
" "Unintentionally!" said [I]_p294.
"Unintentionally?" replied the stranger,  raising [his]_p295 voice a little.

"Was [it]_p296 unintentionally that the [Abraham Lincoln]_n85 pursued [me]_p300 all over the seas? Was [it]_p297 unintentionally that [you]_p302 took passage in this frigate? Was [it]_p297 unintentionally that [your]_p303 cannon-balls rebounded off the plating of [my]_p304 vessel? Was [it]_p298 unintentionally that [Mr Ned Land]_n86 struck [me]_p301 with [his]_p305 harpoon?"[I]_p306 detected a restrained irritation in these words.
But to these recriminations [I]_p307 had a very natural answer to make,  and [I]_p308 made [it]_p309.
"Sir ,"said [I]_p310 ,"no doubt [you]_p311 are ignorant of the discussions which have taken place concerning [you]_p312 in [America]_n87 and [Europe]_n88.
[You]_p313 do not know that divers accidents,  caused by collisions with [your]_p314 submarine machine,  have excited public feeling in the two continents.
[I]_p315 omit the theories without number by which [it]_p316 was sought to explain that of which [you]_p317 alone possess the secret.

But [you]_p318 must understand that, in pursuing [you]_p319 over the high seas of the [Pacific]_n89, the [Abraham Lincoln]_n90 believed [itself]_p320 to be chasing some powerful sea-monster, of which [it]_p321 was necessary to rid the ocean at any price.
" A half-smile curled the lips of the commander: then,  in a calmer tone: "M.

[Aronnax]_n91 ,"[he]_p322 replied ,"dare [you]_p323 affirm that [your]_p324 frigate would not as soon have pursued and cannonaded a submarine boat as a monster?"This question embarrassed [me]_p325, for certainly [Captain Farragut]_n92 might not have hesitated.
[He]_p326 might have thought [it]_p327 [his]_p328 duty to destroy a contrivance of this kind,  as [he]_p329 would a gigantic narwhal.
"[You]_p330 understand then,  sir, " continued the stranger,  "that [I]_p331 have the right to treat [you]_p333 as enemies?" [I]_p332 answered nothing,  purposely.

For what good would [it]_p334 be to discuss such a proposition,  when force could destroy the best arguments? "[I]_p335 have hesitated some time, " continued the commander "nothing obliged [me]_p336 to show [you]_p337 hospitality.

If [I]_p338 chose to separate [myself]_p342 from [you]_p343,  [I]_p339 should have no interest in seeing [you]_p344 again [I]_p339 could place [you]_p344 upon the deck of this vessel which has served [you]_p345 as a refuge,  [I]_p340 could sink beneath the waters,  and forget that [you]_p345 had ever existed.
Would not that be [my]_p348 right?" "[It]_p349 might be the right of a savage, " [I]_p350 answered,  "but not that of a civilised man.

""[Professor]_n93 ,"replied the commander, quickly ,"[I]_p351 am not what [you]_p354 call a civilised man! [I]_p352 have done with society entirely, for reasons which [I]_p352 alone have the right of appreciating.
[I]_p355 do not,  therefore,  obey [its]_p357 laws,  and [I]_p356 desire [you]_p358 never to allude to [them]_p359 before [me]_p360 again!" This was said plainly.
A flash of anger and disdain kindled in the eyes of the Unknown,  and [I]_p361 had a glimpse of a terrible past in the life of this man.

Not only had [he]_p362 put [himself]_p368 beyond the pale of human laws,  but [he]_p363 had made [himself]_p369 independent of [them]_p370,  free in the strictest acceptation of the word,  quite beyond [their]_p371 reach! Who then would dare to pursue [him]_p372 at the bottom of the sea,  when,  on [its]_p375 surface,  [he]_p363 defied all attempts made against him? What vessel could resist the shock of [his]_p376 submarine monitor? What cuirass,  however thick,  could withstand the blows of [his]_p377 spur? No man could demand from [him]_p373 an account of [his]_p377 actions God,  if [he]_p364 believed in one,  [his]_p378 conscience,  if [he]_p364 had one,  were the sole judges to whom [he]_p364 was answerable.
These reflections crossed [my]_p380 mind rapidly,  whilst the stranger personage was silent,  absorbed,  and as if wrapped up in [himself]_p381.
[I]_p382 regarded [him]_p383 with fear mingled with interest, as, doubtless, [OEdiphus]_n94 regarded the [Sphinx]_n95.
After rather a long silence,  the commander resumed the conversation.
